channel.title: 317 > other revisions
channel.description:
This thread is mainly for the liberty of newer users.
Let's face it, you've come here because you've played runescape at some point in your life and you have the urge to create a private server so that you and your friends can chill on it. That's everybody's first idea. But if any of you are like me, it doesn't stop there. You become intrigued. You realise there's quite a lot to this "programming" stuff even though the game code looks like nonsense to you.
I'm here to tell you to begin programming on a 317, even if you move to a newer revision later on. Here are some of my reasons:
1) 317 servers were the first servers ever produced, and therefore are better documented. Without question. If you take ten minutes of your time to look at the RS Wiki, you will note that the 317 protocol has the most information.
2) Generally, there is more support for a 317. If you have a problem with a 317, most users of this forum will be able to help you and support you in some way. Sure, some users can help you with 700+, but your support is relatively very limited
3) 317 is easier to pick up. Seriously? If you're a new member, go download Phonescape or another classic server. Begin to look through it. Note the structure and how the game code is placed together in such a brutal yet effective way. I started on Phonescape back in '08 and to this day I remember being taken to the East Varrock bank and thinking "omg how did I spawn here?!?!?!?!?!". Inquisitively lead to me finding out about a crappy method called ResetPlayerVars which ran once when you first logged in
4) 317's have more content. There's a lot of poor code out there, but much of it works. What many people fail to realise is it's where the bad code is used. For example, the other week I installed a fishing system on some kids AllstarScape. The code wasn't the best. But why does it need to be? If you really want to be picky about server code, you should start with removing the thread per client.
5) 317 clients have more edits than other revisions clients out there. If you want to edit your client in a certain way, there are more tutorials and client hacks for 317 clients than the other revisions
6) 317 servers do not have to send map data. Many may be thinking this is an idiotic remark as we can dump map data now. But even in the latest revisions, we have reports of map data getting corrupted and often not showing whole sections of the world map. 317's do not have this problem and never will.
7) If you wish to move on to a later revision, you can forward your experience of identifying packets to help you understand the later revisions better. If you know that the click-to-attack method in a 317 in 74 (I think off the top of my head!) you can use this knowledge of identifying packets and bring it forward to assist you in your later revisions
Inb4 tl;dr start with 317's. More info on them.

item.title: 317 > other revisions
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

You misinterpreted what I said. You thought I said wL was good or something like that.

Read full topic

item.title: 317 > other revisions
item.dc:creator: @Christmas_tree Christmas_tree
item.description:
@Christmas_tree wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:28, topic:478706”]I just load the maps we do have into the cache and remove the encryption.

The crap between you and Ryley.[/quote]

Yeah, I thought you’d do it that way.

@Atomic why are we arguing again?

Read full topic

item.title: 317 > other revisions
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:28, topic:478706”]I just load the maps we do have into the cache and remove the encryption.

The crap between you and Ryley.[/quote]

Not crap, you’re the one who ultimately made me believe that good hardware and a TCP, Java blocking IO design is good.

[quote=“Christmas_tree, post:25, topic:478706”][quote author=AtomicInt_ link=topic=596928.msg4211853#msg4211853 date=1359678534]

…it really shouldn’t be if it is. What about NPC updating. Appearance updating. Thread per client. No events, shit shoved in process. What about the random nulling and deadlocks due to the structure of winterLove.

Makes fighting over an enum or a switch or whatever seem completely pointless

TPC is conventional on a machine with good hardware. Blocking IO is nice on a good machine. The rest you mentioned is very… uh for lack of a better term bad.
[/quote]

Don’t you dare try and start selling winterLove off as a program that does those things well, because you are misinformed.[/quote]

When did I ever say anything about wL doing things well? I said that TPC w/ jbio runs nice on a good machine.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Christmas_tree Christmas_tree
item.description:
@Christmas_tree wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:26, topic:478706”]ITT: People without actual server development experience spewing crap.

Preference of clients goes as follows: 4xx-5xx, 6xx-650, 3xx-4xx

Why? 4xx had a good mixture of old and new engine features, 6xx-650 had a lot of good engine features and the lobby, 3xx-4xx is last because I’ve been working with it for too long and the graphics have worn on me.[/quote]

…but for later 400’s you have mapdata which for some revisions we don’t have much of.

Please indicate where the crap is located as well

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

[quote=“Christmas_tree, post:21, topic:478706”][quote author=AtomicInt_ link=topic=596928.msg4211728#msg4211728date=1359666299]
You can expand firstly, why is it overkill?
[/quote]

I explained above…code efficiency for fishing (that was my example) is going to make hardly any difference because there are so many big things to worry about in a winterLove server.

Obviously it does make a difference. But it’s not really a pressing concern considering most wL’s still loop player updating through every player instead of a 16*16 region.[/quote]

Your point is invalid, Apollo also iterates through all entities for updating.

Read full topic

item.title: 317 > other revisions
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

[quote=“Christmas_tree, post:11, topic:478706”][quote author=Clawz fury link=topic=596928.msg4203703#msg4203703 date=1358616566]
Well a better alternative would be to create an enum and go with an object-orientated design. This isn’t just more efficient, but it’s actually easier to work with. You are right about what you said in the post above me though. To improve server performance you have to improve code that is running the majority of the time. I remember blakeman8192 said something about it a long time ago… its the 80:20 principal or something like that.
[/quote]

An enum design with an oo design would be perfect, but possibly in some peoples eyes overkill for something as basic as fishing. It would be suitable for a server that was holding above 1000 players at which point it would show a small but evident difference, but even then why would you need to use an enum? Beautiful, admittedly - and absolutely the best way to do it. But overkill.:[/quote]

Using an Enumeration isn’t the best way and it is not overkill what so ever.

Read full topic

item.title: 317 > other revisions
item.dc:creator: @asshole_rule asshole_rule
item.description:
@asshole_rule wrote:

Clawz fury:

Well a better alternative would be to create an enum and go with an object-orientated design. This isn’t just more efficient, but it’s actually easier to work with. You are right about what you said in the post above me though. To improve server performance you have to improve code that is running the majority of the time. I remember blakeman8192 said something about it a long time ago… its the 80:20 principal or something like that.

Which he further stated was NPC updating and player updating

Read full topic

item.title: 317 > other revisions
item.dc:creator: @Christmas_tree Christmas_tree
item.description:
@Christmas_tree wrote:

Clawz fury:

Well a better alternative would be to create an enum and go with an object-orientated design. This isn’t just more efficient, but it’s actually easier to work with. You are right about what you said in the post above me though. To improve server performance you have to improve code that is running the majority of the time. I remember blakeman8192 said something about it a long time ago… its the 80:20 principal or something like that.

An enum design with an oo design would be perfect, but possibly in some peoples eyes overkill for something as basic as fishing. It would be suitable for a server that was holding above 1000 players at which point it would show a small but evident difference, but even then why would you need to use an enum? Beautiful, admittedly - and absolutely the best way to do it. But overkill.

Read full topic

item.title: 317 > other revisions
item.dc:creator: @Christmas_tree Christmas_tree
item.description:
@Christmas_tree wrote:

Yes, it would buy let’s face it. It’s such an insignificant amount compared to the inefficiency of the login block and the fact that wL loops player updating through every player instead of players within your 16x16 region.

If you want to improve efficiency, concentrate on the big things, not the small.

Read full topic

item.title: 317 > other revisions
item.dc:creator: @asshole_rule asshole_rule
item.description:
@asshole_rule wrote:

[quote=“Christmas_tree, post:7, topic:478706”][quote author=Clawz fury link=topic=596928.msg4203479#msg4203479 date=1358566695]
agree with most of the things you stated except 4) which is just stupid logic. Why write horrible code just to release it and have other people learn from your horrible code. That way of thinking is the reason we have this PI problem.
[/quote]

I think you misunderstand. Lets take fishing as an example shall we? Now if i was to program a fishing base, i’d use a switch statement like:

      switch (fish) {
         case 1: // shrimp
         break;
         case 2: //salmon
         break
         default: //dealt cases
         break;
      }

But the alternative to this would be creating an array. Does it matter which one is more efficient? Really? imo no.[/quote]

It kind of does, lol.

Read full topic
